title: Stonelake sells 7 El Paso industrial buildings for $124M, remains big market player
description: Dallas developer Stonelake Capital Partners remains big player in El Paso industrial market after it sells 7 buildings for $124 million.
content:
One of the big players in El Paso’s industrial real estate market has sold seven buildings in East El Paso for $124 million to an investment fund.

The El Paso portfolio was one of 13 sale transactions that Stonelake Capital Partners competed for $920 million in the first half of 2025 in six markets, four of which were in Texas, the Dallas company announced in July.

The sale comes as the El Paso area's industrial property vacancy rate increased to 10.7% in the second quarter of this year, compared to 5.7% in the same quarter in 2024, reported real estate services firm CBRE Group.

The vacancy rate, which had been steadily increasing in recent months, slowed in the second quarter thanks to strong leasing activity, CBRE reported. However, three large speculative buildings coming on the market without tenants boosted the vacancy rate, CBRE reported.

The vacancy rate has been increasing since hitting a record low of 0.6% at the end of 2022 as construction of warehousing/distribution centers boomed to meet demand from manufacturers across the U.S.-Mexico border in Juárez.

Construction of new industrial buildings remains strong in El Paso, CBRE reported, even as President Donald Trump's threats of higher tariffs against Mexico add uncertainty in the manufacturing industry in Mexico and the logistics/warehousing sector in El Paso that supports it.

The Juárez industrial vacancy rate also increased in the second quarter to 8.4%, compared to 4.8% in the same quarter in 2024. New industrial construction has slowed in Juárez, CBRE reported.

Stonelake sold the El Paso properties for $124 million to Invesco, an Atlanta investment firm that bought them for an investment portfolio it manages for the Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board, known as MassPRIM, reported John Bryant, a Stonelake investments director. MassPRIM is an investment service for the retirement assets of Massachusetts teachers and other government employees.

The seven mammoth buildings in East El Paso were purchased by Stonelake in 2017 and 2018, as it began building its industrial building portfolio in Texas and other Sunbelt states, El Paso Central Appraisal District information shows.

More: El Paso's Hunt gets majority ownership in Atlanta's Carter real estate development firm

Four buildings at 12120 to 12170 Rojas Drive, and another nearby at 1313 Don Haskins Drive, which house warehousing/logistics and manufacturing companies, are in what is known as the Vista Del Sol Industrial Submarket. The other two are at 11350 James Watt Drive, which houses a warehousing/logistics company, and a huge warehouse at 1330 Goodyear Drive.

Stonelake remains a major industrial building owner and developer in El Paso and in several other Sunbelt markets.

It owns 27 industrial buildings in the El Paso market. It's uncertain if it remains the second-largest industrial building owner in this market, as it was in 2022 when it owned 36 buildings.

It developed, and continues to own the six-building Eastlake Logistics Park, completed in 2024, at Emerald Spring and Rojas drives, next to the giant Amazon fulfillment center, in East El Paso County.

And it plans to start construction this summer on the second building in the 375 & Montana Logistics Park, at Montana Avenue and Joe Battle Boulevard in East El Paso, after leasing the industrial park’s first building.

“Stonelake will continue to execute on our investment strategy of both acquiring and developing light industrial warehouses to create portfolios of institutional-size and quality in infill locations in markets experiencing significant population growth,” Kenneth Aboussie, Stonelake managing partner, said in a statement.

Vic Kolenc may be reached at 915-546-6421; vkolenc@elpasotimes.com; @vickolenc on Twitter, now known as X.

El Paso’s industrial real estate market

summary: Stonelake Capital Partners, a major player in El Paso's industrial real estate market, has sold seven buildings in East El Paso for $124 million to an investment fund, Invesco, an Atlanta investment firm. The sale was part of 13 sale transactions that Stonelake announced in July that competed for $920 million in six markets, four of which were in Texas. This comes as the El Paso area's industrial property vacancy rate increased to 10.7% in Q2, compared to the same quarter in 2024. The vacancy rate has been increasing since hitting a record low of 0.6% at the end of 2022 due to construction of warehousing/distribution centers across the U.S.-Mexico border in Juárez. Despite President Donald Trump's threats of higher tariffs against Mexico, the industrial sector remains strong, despite uncertainty over the manufacturing industry in Mexico and the logistics/warehousing sector in El El Paso that supports it.
shortSummary: Stonelake Capital Partners sold seven El Paso industrial buildings for $124 million to Invesco, maintaining its major market presence amid rising vacancy rates and strong leasing activity in the area.

scraped_sources.text:
El Paso area in midst of record-setting warehouse and distribution construction boom
The El Paso area is in the midst of a record-setting construction boom of huge, multimillion-dollar warehouse/distribution buildings.
The boom is mostly fueled by the growing manufacturing industry across the border in Juárez. More companies are moving manufacturing from China to Mexico because of pandemic-related supply chain issues, said Bill Caparis, executive vice president at the El Paso office of CBRE Group, the Dallas-based global commercial real estate services company handling several of the new El Paso industrial projects.
“The more (manufacturing) space that gets leased in Juárez, the more demand we see in El Paso,” Caparis said.
Companies with plants in Juárez use El Paso as a warehouse and distribution hub. (A list of El Paso projects is at the end of this story).
The industrial space vacancy rates in El Paso and Juárez were at record lows at the end of the first quarter: 1.5% in El Paso, and just under 1% in Juárez, CBRE data show.
Another reason for the construction boom is pandemic-related supply-chain problems are prompting companies to warehouse more raw materials and finished products than prior to the pandemic, Caparis and others in the industry said.
"Just-in-time inventory was the mantra” prior to the pandemic, said Will Brown, managing partner for Sonny Brown Associates, an El Paso commercial real estate services company. “Now, suppliers and producers recognize the need to have more available inventory” and that’s increased the demand for warehouse space, Brown said.
The need for "safety stock to counter supply-chain disruption" also is fueling demand for warehouse space throughout the United States, a CBRE national report noted.
This is the best El Paso-area industrial real estate market and the most construction happening at one time that Caparis has seen in his 26-year real estate career in El Paso, he said.
At the end of the first quarter, El Paso’s industrial space construction was at a record pace with 11 buildings containing 4.2 million square feet of space under construction, CBRE reported. Seven of those buildings, with 2 million square feet of space, were speculative projects, meaning they were being built without signed tenants – the most speculative space construction built in El Paso at one time, the CBRE report stated.
That comes after a record-setting 2021, which included construction of the five-story, 2.6-million-square-foot Amazon distribution center in far East El Paso County. Amazon officials previously reported the facility was 625,000 square feet, which is only its footprint.
More: 2.6 million square foot Amazon distribution center is largest industrial building in area
Almost half of the square footage under construction in the first quarter is a giant distribution center being built by TJX Companies to supply some of its Marshalls clothing stores. CBRE had the building at 1.7 million square feet, but a TJX official recently told the El Paso Times it will be 2 million square feet.
Neither the Amazon or TJX projects are linked to Mexico.
In Juárez, industrial construction also is at a record pace. At the end of the first quarter, 24 buildings, most of those tied to manufacturing, with 5.5 million square feet of space, were under construction, CBRE researchers found. Seventeen of those buildings with 3 million square feet of space, were speculative projects.
El Paso had 63 million square feet of industrial space, including manufacturing facilities, at the end of the first quarter of 2022; and Juárez had 77 million square feet, most of that manufacturing space, CBRE reported.
Most of the new warehouse/distribution building construction is in far East El Paso because companies want to be near the Zaragoza international bridge, one of the nation’s busiest land ports for commercial, border crossings, and to be near the Interstate 10/Loop 375 interchange, key links for truck traffic. Some speculative industrial space also is being built in Santa Teresa, New Mexico — near El Paso's West Side — where a land port is located.
More: West El Paso's Montecillo continues growing with $80 million in new apartment construction
Recently completed speculative projects in El Paso are leasing quickly – mostly to logistics companies, those in the real estate industry reported.
"There’s a lot of pent-up demand for industrial space on both sides of the border," said Adin Brown, president of Sonny Brown Associates. “This area in my 38 years (in the commercial real estate business) had some nice increases in inventory at various times, but 2020 through 2022 is the most we’ve seen at one time. It’s exciting action."
CBRE’s Caparis doesn’t see the demand slowing down anytime soon.
“There doesn’t appear to be anything we can point to that will change this,” Caparis said. “Interest rates are continuing to rise now; obviously there’s all kinds of things going on around the world that leave a lot of questions. But with the supply-chain issues and the companies through their near-shoring efforts, we think the future for the Mexico markets and border markets will be strong for the foreseeable future.”
New industrial building projects
Some of the new warehouse/distribution projects in the El Paso area:
Constellation Trade Center
Three-building, 798,470-square-foot project expected to begin construction this summer on 52.3 acres next to the newly opened El Paso Logistics Center, near the Socorro school district football stadium in East El Paso. Constellation Real Estate Partners, a year-old industrial building developer with offices in Houston and Dallas, and a real estate fund managed by Dallas' Crow Holdings Capital are doing the project.
El Paso Logistics Park
The 59-acre park’s four-building, 514,135 square-foot first phase was completed in September. Most of the space has been leased to five companies, and a sixth lease is pending for the remaining space, reported a spokesperson for VanTrust Real Estate, a large Kansas City, Missouri, real estate development company overseeing the project. The two-building, 480,504 square-foot second phase is under construction. The park is between Mercantile Avenue and Paseo Del Este Boulevard in East El Paso.
Rojas East Distribution Center
The two-building, 369,310-square-foot project at 12590 Rojas Drive, near Eastlake Boulevard, was completed in July and has been leased to two companies. Dallas-based Hunt Southwest Real Estate Development Co., developed and owns the project.
Eastlake Logistics Park
Walls are rising on the six-building, 1.1 million-square-foot project at Emerald Spring and Rojas drives, next to the new Amazon distribution center in far East El Paso County. The three-building, first phase is expected to be completed by the end of 2022. Stonelake Capital Partners, a Dallas-based commercial real estate developer, is doing the project.
Pan American industrial park additions
Three warehouses with 304,303 square feet of space at 9577 Plaza Circle and 455 Pan American Drive in the Pan American industrial park, near the Zaragoza international bridge in the Lower Valley. Construction is to be completed in late 2022 and early 2023. The buildings are being developed by a joint venture of Boston's Equity Industrial Partners and New York's Raith Capital Partners on land it acquired in late 2019 along with 22 industrial buildings.
Americas Ten 2
A 168,000-square-foot building almost completed at 12290 Rojas Drive in East El Paso. The $14.1 million project, being done by EastGroup Properties, a Mississippi real estate investment trust and developer, is next to EastGroup's 98,000-square-foot industrial building opened 20 years ago.
Westpark Building 2
The 364,500-square-foot building in the Westpark Logistics Center in Santa Teresa, New Mexico, a part of El Paso's West Side industrial market, is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2022. It's next to the 315,000-square-foot Westpark Building 1 completed in 2021 and fully leased. Blue Road Investments, a Dallas industrial land developer, is the project developer.
Vic Kolenc may be reached at 546-6421; vkolenc@elpasotimes.com; @vickolenc on Twitter.

Trump delays Mexico tariffs' hike; most Mexico factory output expected to remain exempt
Editor's note: This story has been updated with details about 90-day delay of planned, Aug. 1 increase on U.S. tariffs for some Mexico imports.
The tariffs are increasing, the tariffs are increasing.
That’s been President Donald Trump’s calling card in the first six months of his second presidential term.
For Mexico, that means the planned Aug. 1 increase of U.S. tariffs from 25% to 30% on some imports of Mexican-made products is being delayed 90 days.
Trump announced the extension on a Truth Social platform post Thursday morning.
"The complexities of a Deal with Mexico are somewhat different than other Nations because of both the problems, and assets, of the Border," Trump wrote.
So, he and Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum, during a phone conversation, agreed to extend for 90 days the current tariffs, which include 50% tariffs on Mexico-imported steel, Trump said.
And Mexico agreed to immediately terminate its non-tariff trade barriers, Trump said. He did not give details on the trade barriers, except to say "there are many."
Sheinbaum wrote on a X social media platform post, which is translated in this story from Spanish, "We had a very good call with United States President Donald Trump. We avoided the tariff increase announced for tomorrow and secured 90 days to build a long-term agreement through dialogue."
European Union deal puts U.S. tariffs at 15%
The Mexico extension comes days after the Trump administration reached a deal to lower the tariff on the European Union of 27 countries to 15% from the 30% tariffs planned to also begin Aug. 1.
That's still higher than European leaders had wanted. European steel imports to the U.S. will remain at 50%.
Trump said July 28, that 15% represents the new standard for tariff negotiations, Yahoo Finance reported.
Mexico products made under USMCA expected to be exempt
The prevailing opinion in the cross-border trade community is that most imports from Mexico will remain exempt from the U.S. tariffs under the United States Mexico Canada (trade) Agreement, or USMCA, Garrick Taylor, a spokesman for the Border Trade Alliance, an advocacy organization for trade between the U.S. and Mexico, said in an email.
That should mean much of the factory production from Mexico, including in Juárez, just across the border from El Paso, should be spared from new tariffs implemented by the Trump administration.
Many U.S. companies operate factories in Mexico. And many manufacturing suppliers in El Paso and other areas along the U.S.-Mexico border rely on selling parts and other materials to manufacturers in Mexico.
El Paso and other border areas in the United States also have a large logistics industry supporting the cross-border trade, marked by the huge warehouse/distribution centers along the border.
Just over 80% of imports from Mexico to the U.S., are exempted from U.S. tariffs, mainly due to exemptions on goods compliant under the USMCA, the Bloomberg News service recently reported.
“While we’re hopeful that USMCA-compliant trade will remain tariff-free, we are disappointed at the threat of new tariffs and their potential to undermine the strength of the North American economy,” Taylor said
The tariffs are taxes paid by companies importing goods to the U.S., from various countries. They are bringing in billions of dollars of revenue to the U.S. treasury, federal officials have said. However, they also can bring product price increases as companies pass on at least some of the tariffs' costs to U.S. customers.
Tariffs increase costs in Texas factories
Prices for manufacturers' raw materials and finished goods rose further in June in Texas, southern New Mexico and northern Louisiana due to increases in tariffs, including on steel, the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas recently reported. Prices for steel made in the U.S. also have risen as demand has increased, it reported.
The increase in U.S. tariffs prompted some countries, most notably China, to insitute recripricol tariffs against U.S.-exported products.
More: Helen of Troy market value plummets as China tariffs continue to hurt business
Steel, tomatoes have separate tariffs
Besides the United States' 30% tariffs planned to begin for some Mexico imports Aug. 1, other tariffs are already in place:
The U.S. increased tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from most countries, including Mexico, from 25% to 50% in June.
However, U.S. and Mexico officials are negotiating a deal to reduce or eliminate the tariffs on steel imports up to a certain volume, Reuters news service reported in June.
The U.S. imposed a 17.1 % tariff on most tomato imports from Mexico beginning July 14 after the U.S. Department of Commerce ended an agreement with Mexico that suspended the tariff instituted in 1996 after tomato growers in the U.S. petitioned for help because they claimed they were being hurt by dumped imports of Mexican-grown tomatoes, according to the State Department.
U.S. tomato-grower groups applauded the tariff while U.S. produce importer groups said it will hurt their industry by reducing imports, and hurt consumers who, they said, will pay higher tomato prices.
“Mexico remains one of our greatest allies, but for far too long our farmers have been crushed by unfair trade practices that undercut pricing on produce like tomatoes," U.S. Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick said in a statement released July 14.
Produce exporters and growers remain concerned about tariffs. Fifteen groups representing produce exporters and growers, several from Canada, in a July 24 letter urged Trump, Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum, and Canada Prime Minister Mark Carney "to work together to reach a long-term agreement that will restore a stable trading environment for our essential (produce) products.'
Vic Kolenc may be reached at 915-546-6421; vkolenc@elpasotimes.com; @vickolenc on Twitter, now known as X.
More: El Paso Electric substation construction boom aims to meet big energy demands

Amazon gives glimpse inside its huge distribution center in East El Paso
More than a year after beginning operations, Amazon officials finally opened the doors of its mammoth distribution center in far East El Paso County on Tuesday to give the public a look inside via a news media tour.
About 2,000 people work there to pick, pack and ship about 200,000 to 500,000 products per day for Amazon.com customers, with the help of hundreds of robotic carriers and miles of conveyor belts, said Jon Kot, the facility’s general manager.
Kot, 32, is an El Paso native and Franklin High School graduate who returned home to manage what is officially known as ELP1, an Amazon robotics fast, sortable fulfillment center. He’s worked for Amazon for nine years.
The center has little employee turnover and isn't scheduled to hire again until its busier seasons in the summer, when the Amazon Prime Day sale is held, and in the fall for the holiday shopping season, Kot said.
Eighty-five percent of the workforce is full-time, and the others are seasonal workers, Kot said
The starting wage is $16 per hour, higher than when the facility opened in November 2021. It also has a strong package of fringe benefits, Kot said.
More: El Paso City Council sets $15 per hour minimum wage goal for city workforce
The facility has 2.6 million square feet inside five floors and covers about 13 football fields near Eastlake Boulevard and Rojas Drive in a booming commercial area outside the El Paso city limits. It’s the largest industrial building by square footage in El Paso.
Several fast-food outlets, a gas station and a car wash have sprung up along the edges of the Amazon building. And a Home Depot is under construction next to it on Eastlake Boulevard. The new Eastlake Market and Eastlake Commons shopping centers are across the street from the Amazon facility.
Inside the fulfillment center, yellow bins carrying various products zip along conveyor belts to various stations, where workers first unpack items delivered from other Amazon facilities or vendors and then send them to other stations, where they are sorted with the help of tall robotic shelf towers and then sent to be packed by employees at other stations.
About 4,000 robotic carriers and devices and other automated systems are used to speed the processing of orders, Kot said.
About 300 to 600 people work per shift, depending on the volume of orders, Kot said. The facility operates 23 hours per day, with one hour set aside for building maintenance, he said.
The El Paso center handles only products that are 18 inches in diameter or less. Bigger items are sent to other Amazon fulfillment centers. Amazon has about 400 fulfillment centers of various sizes in the United States, Kot said.
The El Paso center doesn’t ship items directly to Amazon.com customers. That’s done mostly through Amazon delivery facilities, all located in other cities. One was expected to be built on city government-owned land in West El Paso, but the land deal collapsed.
Vic Kolenc may be reached at 546-6421; vkolenc@elpasotimes.com; @vickolenc on Twitter.

El Paso's Hunt gets majority ownership in Atlanta's Carter real estate development firm
El Paso’s Hunt Companies has added to its growing portfolio by acquiring majority ownership in Carter, an Atlanta real estate investment and development firm that Hunt has partnered with on two large Florida projects.
Hunt bought the Carter ownership held by Bob Peterson, a longtime Carter executive who retired as the company’s board chairman July 15, along with a small number of other investor stakes, a Hunt spokesperson said.
No financial details were disclosed.
One of Carter's better-known projects is redevelopment of a neighborhood after the Atlanta Braves moved out.
Hunt is a national real estate development and management group headed by well-known El Paso businessman Woody Hunt. It’s based in the WestStar Tower that the company helped build in Downtown El Paso. It’s developed large residential communities in East and West El Paso.
Carter is a 67-year-old company with more than $1 billion worth of active real estate developments throughout the Southeast United States, including mixed-use and multifamily projects, according to information on its website.
Hunt officials became familiar with Carter when they partnered with the Atlanta company to build the luxury, 180-unit DeSota apartment complex, completed in 2018, in Sarasota, Florida.
The two companies also are partners in developing the 22-acre Lake Wire mixed-use development, which broke ground in early 2023, in Lakeland, Florida’s Downtown area. The project’s first phase, with 300 luxury apartments and 15,000 square-feet of retail space, was recently completed.
Carter’s management, including CEO Scott Taylor, and its 22 employees will remain at its headquarters in the Atlanta Summerhill neighborhood that Carter helped redevelop after the Atlanta Braves major league baseball team moved out of its stadium located there and left acres of empty parking lots.
The deal won’t add jobs in El Paso, where 188 of Hunt’s 2,257 employees are located, the Hunt spokesperson said.
“But the acquisition presents growth opportunities for both companies in the ability to pursue new business in mixed-use and multi-family development,” according to a Hunt statement.
Hunt's strategic expertise and financial strength will allow Carter to expand its mixed-use development footprint throughout the Sunbelt states, “identifying high-value residential projects that foster long-term value for investors and clients," according to the companies’ deal announcement.
Carter has no current plans for projects in El Paso, but “we’re certainly open to the opportunity,” Carter’s Taylor said in a statement.
More: El Paso's Hunt Companies acquires huge Marine Corps housing portfolio in Eastern US
Ryan McCrory, new Hunt president, said in a statement that Carter has an impressive record in real estate development.
“Our successful (Florida) collaborations demonstrate the strong foundation we already share,” McCrory said. “With this partnership, we’re leveraging our combined strengths to accelerate growth while maintaining focus on quality, innovation, and sustainability.”
Vic Kolenc may be reached at 915-546-6421; vkolenc@elpasotimes.com; @vickolenc on Twitter, now known as X.

argos_summary: Stonelake Capital Partners has sold seven industrial buildings in East El Paso for $124 million to Invesco, as part of a larger $920 million portfolio sale across multiple markets. The El Paso area is experiencing a rise in industrial property vacancy rates, now at 10.7%, up from 5.7% a year prior, largely due to new speculative constructions entering the market. Despite this, strong leasing activity continues, and construction of new industrial buildings remains robust, driven by demand from the manufacturing sector across the U.S.-Mexico border.
